title: Who were Rome’s best emperors? The list is terrifyingly short. Augustus, coldeyed brute that he was, reduced the power struggles of the late republic to exhausted order and established mechanisms for ruling the wide empire from a small center; Trajan and Hadrian understood empire and its demands and solidified and professionalized an army and a government after a century of Augustus’s successors had done no more than terrorize; Diocletian rescued and restored empire, by force of a vast expansion of government
